Blog.post: Just trying it out
It's nice not having a signal in the library, no one can call me :)

My gosh, who ever thought we'd all be so interested in birds all of a sudden. A few weeks ago I wouldn never have thought I'd spend the whole afternoon running around the backyards looking up trees to find some little birds :) Here's a movie of dad squaking at me www.student.yorku.ca/~skrausz/robin-movie.avi

urlLink And here's the chikadee (had a branch in it's beak earlier). Maybe we can look forward to some more little birds on the way? Can this new family make up for the loss of our robins? I donno, we'll have to wait and see. In the meantime, I'm still keeping an eye pealed for the robins (and it's so annoying, they MUST be here somewhere since their parents are still around) but I don't have my hopes too high.
urlLink But look - now there's a chikadee nest being built on the side wall! Wow, birds really like us! Stay tuned...
urlLink Here's dad looking at at again

urlLink Well, after searching all day still not sign of the kids. Father (mother?) keeps squaking at us when we get to a certain part of the yard but we don't see anything. I guess they're either hiding or the flew away :(

Went looking for the 'kids' again today but can't seem to see them. We're still convinced they're in the same trees they were in before because the moment I get close to the tree, BOTH mom and dad start flying around like crazy, chirping and squaking at me until I leave - they're probably protecting them. We read up a bit about robins and apparently, they are most vulnerable for the first 3 days after leaving the nest, especially to cats who often try catching them since they don't fly much. Also, if the nest was successful, the mother will make another nest nearby and lay eggs again (and possibly a third time again later). The interesting thing is that the father will continue to care for the baby robins for up to three weeks after leaving the nest! They must all stay nearby, so I'm confident we'll find them again. Going to try doing a thorough search again tommorrow.

Well, as evening came around we still couldn't find the others. We saw Marc hop down the branch and out of sight a while back (can't see him anymore) and Mom and dad still fly around some bushes and trees we have, but it's hard to see anything hiding there. Chances are good everyone is still somewhere in the backyard, at least for another day or two since they don't seem to be able to fly much and the parents are still watching over them (Still flying all over the place when we go to the backyard). Vivaldi made his way to the middle of the apple tree since his prevoius branch swayed too much in the wind and he kept losing his balance - at least we can see him through our window. Funny, he doesn't seem to be scared of us at all, even when we're close. He even finds us boring, eventually starting to look at other things, even when we're a few feet from him to take a picture (make no mistake, mom and dad still scream at us when we do, they sure know that kids should stay away from strangers). Well, I guess we better leave the little guy alone to get some sleep.

urlLink Vivaldi sure is curious. We opened our door (he's an just over an arm's length away) and he isn't scared. Just sitting there looking at us. Come on Vivaldi, Fly somewhere, hop, jump, chirp, something! Of course, nothing, just sitting there for the past few hours :) Mom and dad come around once in a while with some worms too. Don't forget all the pictures can be clicked for a closeup. Still no sight of the other two.

urlLink Doing some more searching I find Vivadi! (and make no mistake, it is him, we can tell from the little white feathers on his head!) This little guy didn't make it as far as Marc, he's barely 10 feet from the nest in the apple tree by the porch
urlLink Here's mom chirping away "Get away from my kids!"
urlLink Now comes mom with some food, and Marc tries following her down the branch - a little hopping around but after some tripping and slipping he gives up and sits down again
urlLink Just went around the backyard and lo and behold! I found Marc! He was hiding in a nearby tree, just sitting there! Way to go Marc, you flew 20 feet!
urlLink Looks like the all flew away! We're having empty nest syndrome. And who's left to clean up the mess?

urlLink Marc's brother has officially been named Vivaldi! At least Marc can call his brother by name now instead of just 'chirp'. Note that their siblings are hiding from shame since they don't have a name yet :( Suggestions anyone?

urlLink These fellas sure are a curious bunch! I guess they wonder what it is I'm doing exactly with this camera. Marc seems to be the boss around here that's for sure, but where is sibling #4? Seems to be hiding somwhere behind the rest, shy I suppose

urlLink Thanks to Marc for being the first person to offer me a gmail invitation! In honour of Marc, we've decided to name the first robin that hatched after him! See how proud robin Marc is to get his new name? :) Also, got a second invite from Yvonne so I gave it to away to a good cause. Thanks Yvonne! I'm just waiting for your response to my email, what would you like your robin called?
urlLink Our robins want to get out of that crowded nest.
Finally, I'm getting my essay done - it's already minimum length and I have at least another few pages to add. I'll be sure to post it once I'm done for those of you who are (not)interested.
Very not good. This essay I'm working on last minute is not going to well and I need to finish it by tommorrow. What else is new.
Up bright and early this lovely Sunday morning (as usual). Just gonna grab a quick breakfast and head downtown.
Hmmm, not much to say. Just trying to finish up this independent study project. Then all I'll have left is a 10 page essay to do this weekend :)

Now I'm at the Gerstein library at UofT, doing some studying with friends. Checking my York email here is a bit intimidating - I get wierd glances. I better lay low :) Today was my first day with the literacy tutoring. It was kind of awkward at the beginning, but things quickly picked up and we were doing great in no time. I don't think I'm ever going to take the ability to read for granted again, that's for sure.

Since requests for a more exciting and entertaining blog are in such high demand (1 comment out of 2 = 50% of my viewers) I've decided to give in to my fans' demands and do my best to please them. Today I did my weekly volunteer rounds at PMH's CT/MRI clinic. I lvoe watching people's faces light up with joy when they're told that they get to drink their barium sulfate coctail once again (dye that makes the CT image show up better). The flavour on the bottle says Orange. Funny, it looks like milk but has the consistency of chalk mixed with water. Actually that's what it looks like when I make the stuff (one of my jobs). I mix water in these jugs with this nasty white goop. In any case, the flavour is orange, but the only thing that resembles orange is the smell perhaps. The looks I get range from hillarious to pitiful. Some people laugh when I give them the cup (having drunk an entire 2L bottle the night before) while others give me a blank stare and tell me they're rather have chemo than drink that nastiness called Barium juice (yummy sounding too). I make them drink it anyway. It's one of the joys of the job. When told I should drink it instead I tell them I'd love to, but I have to make sure to leave enough for them. Besides that, the volunteer position offers other intangible benefits, such as seeing people put on their hospital gown backwards and watching them walk down the hall with their underwear showing out the back. I mean this is like putting on a bath robe backwards - is it such a hard thing to do? Of course I always end up having to chase them down the hall and inform them that, despite popular belief, hospital staff DO NOT enjoy chasing semi-nude octogenarians down the hall at 9am in the morning. OK, I jest. I do feel sorry for them and don't (usually) let them get that far away. So far I've managed to catch them on time, but it's only a matter of time before one will slip away, and then who knows what will happen. Then of course are the individuals who are obsessed with their weight. An obsese (to put it lightly) man came in, and, when told to change, managed to somehow put on the SMALLEST gown in our collection. You'd think that when the bottom of the gown only reaches your bellybutton, something is wrong. Perhaps, (and correct me if I'm wrong) but just maybe it's time to move to the adult size. But no, it's not obvious enough. We should label our gowns better next time. Put that in the suggestion box. And then come the people who just don't want to read. I mean there are these two big doors with two large stop signs and multiple warnings "Do not open these doors", "STOP here!", "Extremely powerful magnetic fields beyond this point, individuals with metal on their person should not proceed". And on and on. Of course, the logical thing to do, according to some people, is, but of course, to open the door and walk down that hall. Why didn't I think of that? Maybe the powerful magnetic fields will invert their brain cells' molecular dipole moments (OK I just had to put some physics in here) and that will miraculously endow them with the power of reading. Actually, I don't understand it. These people are capable of filling out governmental forms that give me the willies just glancing at, yet big red stop signs are 'no comprende'. There's another one for the suggestion box ("re-lable 'stop! do not cross' doors with governmental form jargon"). After all this excitement, I decided to go downstairs to get a coke. I take the sleek glass elevator do the mezzanine, start walking down the hall, and notice some people standing in line. Hmm. How odd, I wonder why they're standing in the middle of the hall. I shrug it off and continue my walk to Tim Horton's. The strange thing is, I notice this line continuing along my route, and everyone in it staring at me as if to say "Why would you actually be walking to get to your destination? Wouldn't it be better to stand in line and not get anywhere?". I ignore them. Especially since the line continues far into the distance. So far, in fact, that a thich haze envelopes the poor souls at the far end. 2 miles down the hall, I start getting a creepy feeling up my spine. Where IS this line going to? Could it possibly be... Na, but what if?... I begin thinking that maybe these poor people are in for one heck of a surprise. Some prankster started this line, but actually all it does is loop back upon itself. So the people are just waiting to eventually get back to where they currently are! No, I laugh off the thought, especially since I now see the line's continuation passing out the exit door. Even sillier! Why would these people be waiting in line to get out of the building? Isn't it usually the other way around? As I near my destination, the truth hits me in the face like the inevitable custard pie flying into the politicians face (and while we're at it, let's face it, every politician has a custard pie with his or her name on it, and, sooner or later (but hopefully sooner) it will meet it's destiny and be reunited with it's deserving recepient. (For more information on this fascinating topic, I STRONGLY STRONGLY recommend reading the following article at http://www.cnn.com/2000/WORLD/europe/11/23/pie.protest/ it is by far the most enterntaining peice of journalism I have read in a long time)) Now, where was I? Oh yes, the proverbial pie hit me in the face, when I realized that the line did NOT, as I thought, go out the door, but rather doubled back and ended up, believe it (or not, as I did at the time) at Tim Horton's. I was flabbergasted. Could this be? I thought to myself: 1) Could this really be Tim Horton's? 2) Could a line actually be this long? 3) I mean, is it physically possible for a line to be this long? 4) What would Newton say? 5) Could classical mechanics allow for such a length? 6) Failing that, would special relativity correct for this seemingly impossible mobius loop? 7) Failing THAT, would string theory have a solution, or would it necessitate the inclusion of 11 parallel dimensions, an axiom many physicists laud. 7) Speaking of strings. I'm hungry. 8) I wonder what's for dinner? 9) I should call home and get mom to make spaghetti. 10) That reminds me, why am I here? Oh yes, Tim Horton's. I look again in disbelief. All this staring is making me thirsty. But the Tim's Oasis, despite being a mere 5 meters from me, could have just as easily been 5 blocks away. I look around hoplessly. Maybe that nice little old lady will let me bud. "Excuse me, do you think I might be able to....". NO! . Gee! How rude! I mean she seemed like such a sweet old lady! Besides, how does she know I wasn't going to ask her to borrow a pen or a hanky or something. Humpf. I look around. Everyone is now glaring at me, as if saying "Listen bub, if you so much as dare to even approach me, I will slap you so hard that you'll thank me if I throw a custard pie in your face". I decide to try the puppy-face approach. I stand there making my poor old puppy face, and even feint a tear. Nothing. Eventually the old lady throws me a hanky. Thanks. I look around some more, and who's sure to be the 3rd from the front of the line, but Mr. Hospital-Cloak-backwards. What! How did HE get here? I knew he would slip away, he had that sly look on his face. And now here he is, cloak and all. I decide to brave the line. When I finally get to the end again, I notice that it looks much like the beginning - stretching far into the distance, but this time the other way. I ask someone "Isn't this the end of the line?" And the frank reply I get is "Listen bub, does this look like the end of the line to you? I've been waiting since 9am. This is the FRONT of the line". If this is the 'front' part of the line, I shudder at how much farther back I have to walk. Three months later, I finally arrived at Tim Horton's. At first I couldn't believe it, but there I was. Really. I wept for joy. After giving me an odd look, the cashier asks, "What would you like sir?" "A coke please," I answer. "I'm sorry, we don't have coke here". Huh? I couldn't understand her. It sounded like "Commont appelle tu, monsier" (for those of you who don't know french this means 'hurry up and make a choice before I serve the next person in line). At this point I didn't care. "Give me a Pepsi, give me a juice, give me a tea, a coffee, a beer, I don't care, just give me something to drink". "I'm sorry sir," she beamed, "but we're closed for lunch now". Luckily I had a custard pie in my pocket, for just such an occasion. Stay tuned for tommorrow's adventure.

Humpf. It seems from some comments that some anonymous brat seems to think that my blog is boring. Well, if that's the case, I'd like to see YOUR blog. No blog you say? Well no blog is more boring than a dull blog! Blog off! :)
Cognition - all done!

Oh no! I just realized that I forgot to finish reading an entire chapter of the book - I was so bogged down with studying everything else. Now I have 1 hour left to read something that would normally take about 4 hours. Great.

OK, just finished 4 chapters so it's time for a break. I'm starting to notice that this blog is getting a little drab since it's saturated with course/test preparation postings. It'll probably get better after today though. I'm also starting to think about the direction I want this blog to take after things quiet down a bit. I have a feeling I'm going to split into 2 or more sections in a few weeks: The main blog and perhaps another part dealing with photography and/or some other topic. Don't know yet. Oh yeah, and feel free to comment. Link is available at the bottom of each posting. All comments anonymous of course (unless you let me know who you are).
Just got to Scott library, but as son as it comes time to sit down and do the last minute cramming I realize I have to check my email. I can't wait for this thing to be over...

If I don't make it to Wilson station by 9 I give up a decent parking spot. For some reason at exactly 9am every morning all the good spots are taken. That means I have to park across the street. I doubt I'll make it.

urlLink And so, another fruitfull day has come to an end. Of course, once again I didn't finish what I wanted to finish. Not even close. Two more chapters to read for my exam tommorrow and then I'm off to bed. urlLink
First a 10 minutes storm, now all this info on electrostatics, especially Coulombs law - it's making me hungry.
urlLink This makes so much sense... I think... urlLink
I hate the hopeless feeling - when you know you just can't catch up. At this point I'm starting to lose it: Who cares about the differences between heat of transformation and conduction anyways?

Wow, what a difference my day has when the phone is left off! I can't believe how productive I am now. I think this is something I'm going to be trying more often. I guess I'll take a quick break now and check the little robins who just hatched on our eavestrough. 46.1 124
Of course - I wanted to start my day off at 8, but now it's 10. Couldn't sleep last night due to a storm...

Yeah, so today was really long. I think I sat at my desk for most of the day doing biology problems (except for some back and forth email debate on Peak Oil and zero-point energy). It can get lonely in one's room, especially when the folks are busy with their rumikub party downstairs and there's nowhere else to go. That reminds me, this place looks like a pigsty, I should clean it up... G'nite to all.
urlLink Here's mom laying batch # 2. Our guess is they will be hatching in about a week or so.
Some new bird pictures (robin and chickadee) on their way tommorrow. Looks like somethings going to hatch soon!
Just finished a long day of studying. Going to sleep.
Just at a friend's cottage, going home later today
It appears that the robins have returned to lay more eggs! Stay tuned for some pictures in the next few days...
